description: 2G refers to the second-generation of cellular network technology, first commercially launched in 1991. It marked the transition from analog to digital transmission, introducing three key advantages: digitally encrypted phone conversations, more efficient use of radio frequency spectrum enabling more users per frequency band, and mobile data services starting with SMS. The most common 2G technology was GSM, which became the first globally adopted mobile communications framework. Later enhancements (2.5G/2.75G) included GPRS and EDGE, enabling data transfer speeds up to 384 kbit/s.
3G represents the third generation of mobile telecommunications technology, offering faster data transfer speeds and enabling advanced services such as video calling and mobile internet access.

3GPP is a collaboration between groups of telecommunications associations responsible for developing protocols for mobile telecommunications, including GSM, UMTS, LTE, and 5G NR [[3GPP.org]](https://www.3gpp.org/about-3gpp/about-3gpp).

A 3GPP Change Request (CR) is a formal document submitted to propose modifications or enhancements to existing 3GPP technical specifications. CRs follow a structured review and approval process to maintain consistency and quality in telecommunications standards.

3GPP Technical Specifications (TS) define the standardized technical requirements and procedures for mobile communication systems. These specifications cover radio interfaces, core networks, service capabilities, and security aspects, serving as the foundation for global mobile telecommunications standards.

4G refers to the fourth generation of wireless communication technology, providing high-speed internet access and supporting advanced mobile broadband services. It enables speeds up to 100Mbps for mobile users and introduced key technologies like LTE and WiMAX, revolutionizing mobile data consumption through high-quality streaming, video calls, and mobile gaming.

5G is the fifth generation of mobile network technology, introducing revolutionary capabilities including ultra-low latency (<1ms), massive device connectivity (up to 1 million devices per square km), and peak data rates up to 20 Gbps. It enables new use cases across industries through network slicing, edge computing, and advanced radio technologies.

The 5G Core (5GC) is a cloud-native network architecture implementing service-based principles and network function virtualization. It introduces key features like network slicing, edge computing support, and enhanced security through a modular, microservices-based design. The architecture separates control and user planes while supporting both 5G and legacy access networks.
A network element that provides security, interoperability, and session control at the border between different IP networks, specifically focused on the access side of the network.

A suite of features and capabilities that monitor, manage and control application delivery and performance to ensure optimal end-user experience. It includes traffic classification, policy enforcement, and QoS management.

A framework for intelligently controlling access to network resources, enforcing policies, auditing usage, and providing information necessary for billing and analysis. The three security processes work together to ensure secure network management and resource tracking.

A telecommunications system that automatically routes incoming calls to specific agents or departments based on predefined rules, caller requirements, and agent availability. It's crucial for call centers to manage high call volumes efficiently.

A set of properties that guarantee database transactions are processed reliably. Atomicity ensures transactions are all-or-nothing, Consistency ensures data validity, Isolation ensures concurrent transactions don't interfere, and Durability ensures committed transactions remain saved.
A list of permissions attached to an object in a computer system. ACLs specify which users or system processes are granted access to objects, as well as what operations are allowed on given objects.
A technique used in wireless communications that automatically adjusts the modulation scheme based on channel conditions to optimize data throughput while maintaining reliable transmission.

definition: Abstraction and Control of TE Networks
Abstraction and Control of TE Networks
description: Virtualised Network

Content (text, images, audio, video) that is created by artificial intelligence models rather than humans. This includes content from large language models, text-to-image models, and other generative AI systems.

The simulation of human intelligence by machines, particularly computer systems. AI encompasses various subfields including machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics. Modern AI systems leverage deep learning and neural networks to perform complex tasks such as pattern recognition, decision making, language understanding, image processing, and autonomous control. Recent advances include large language models, generative AI, and reinforcement learning systems.
Middle East - Asia - Pacific

definition: Access Network Discovery and Selection Policy

description: A set of standardized protocols and tools that enables different software applications to communicate with each other. APIs define the methods and data formats that applications can use to request and exchange information, forming the foundation of modern software integration and web services.
A language representation model developed by Google, known for its effectiveness in various NLP tasks.
a system that combines batteries with other electrical components to provide a reliable and efficient source of power.
interdomain routing protocol designed to provide loop-free routing between organizations.

definition: Customized Applications for Mobile network Enhanced Logic
description: a set of standards designed to work on either a GSM core network or the UMTS network by extending the services offered within a GSM network. Provides the mechanisms to support operator specific services, which are not covered by standardized GSM services
FlexGrid

definition: European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations

description: A network management approach where systems continuously monitor, analyze, decide, and execute actions without human intervention. It involves collecting data from network elements, analyzing it against policies or AI models, making decisions, and implementing corrective actions automatically, creating a feedback loop that improves over time. Closed loop automation is fundamental to autonomous networks and zero-touch operations.

A telecommunications facility housing switching equipment and network infrastructure that connects subscribers to the broader network. Central offices serve as critical nodes in telecommunications networks, hosting equipment for voice, data, and internet services.

A network element responsible for managing and coordinating network resources, traffic flow, and operational parameters in telecommunications systems. Controllers can operate at various network layers and may handle functions like resource allocation, traffic management, and policy enforcement.
Centralized database storing subscriber information and profiles in telecommunications networks
Network node that handles user plane mobility and acts as gateway between radio and core network
Component that manages control plane functions in the SGSN architecture
Instance of a communication service in network slice management
Reference signals used in 4G/5G systems for channel quality measurement and beamforming
Function responsible for translating communication service requirements to network slice requirements

It's a type of attack that tricks the victim into submitting a malicious request. Django provides built-in protection against CSRF attacks through the {% csrf_token %} template tag and the ensure_csrf_cookie() decorator. This ensures that only authenticated requests are processed, protecting user data and system integrity.
Style sheet language used for describing the presentation of HTML documents
A prompting technique for language models where the model is encouraged to break down complex problems into intermediate steps, showing its reasoning process before arriving at the final answer.

definition: Cisco Secure Client Diagnostics and Reporting Tool

description: In telecommunications, DL refers to the transmission path from a network base station or satellite to the user device, often used in mobile networks like LTE and 5G to define data transfer directionality.

A method for fine-tuning language models to align with human preferences, directly optimizing a policy that best satisfies the preferences without needing an explicit reward model. DPO uses a simple classification loss on preference data (pairs of preferred and dispreferred responses) and has been shown to be as effective or more effective than methods like RLHF, while being simpler to implement and train.
DNN is a parameter used in 5G networks to identify a specific Data Network within the operator's infrastructure, enabling the selection of the appropriate packet data network for connectivity.
DNS is a server that responds to queries by translating domain names into IP addresses, facilitating access to web services and resources over the internet.

DNS is a hierarchical decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network, primarily used to translate human-readable hostnames into numerical IP addresses.

DO refers to a functional component in network orchestration responsible for managing and coordinating workflows across individual domains, ensuring alignment with service-level agreements and policies in virtualized or cloud-native environments.

definition: Data Over Cable Service Interface Specification

description: An optical networking technology that increases bandwidth by transmitting multiple data channels over a single fiber-optic cable using different light wavelengths.
DevOps is a transformative methodology integrating software development and IT operations, emphasizing automation, collaboration, and rapid feedback.
A class of generative models that learn to reverse a gradual noising process to generate data, often used for image generation.

indicates the percentage of the battery that has been discharged relative to the overall capacity of the battery. Depth of Discharge is defined as the capacity that is discharged from a fully charged battery, divided by battery nominal capacity.
the buying and selling of goods and services, or the transmitting of funds or data, over an electronic network, primarily the internet

definition: Fault, Configuration, Accounting, Performance and Security

description: A data structure and processing method where the first element added is the first one to be removed
A measure of computer performance, especially relevant in AI/ML computations and model training
A large AI model trained on broad data that can be adapted for various downstream tasks, serving as a foundation for other AI models
Software that is freely available for anyone to use, modify, and distribute
A computational model used to design systems that can be in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time
A cloud computing model that allows running individual functions in response to events without managing infrastructure
The ability of a model to learn a new task from only a small number of examples provided in the prompt.
The process of adapting a pre-trained model (like an LLM) to a specific task or dataset by training it further on relevant data.
A type of large language model developed by OpenAI, known for its strong text generation capabilities.
a system of interactive visual components for computer software that displays objects which convey information and represent actions that can be taken by the user.

devices which can only transmit in one direction at one time. Although data can move in two directions, it cannot be at the same time. Both devices can transmit and receiving but when one device is sending, the other is receiving

A framework of policies and technologies for ensuring that the proper people in an enterprise have the appropriate access to technology resources. It handles the authentication, authorization, and management of user identities within IT systems.

A capability of large language models to learn new tasks from examples provided in the prompt without updating model weights. The model uses examples in the input context to understand and perform new tasks.

definition: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers

description: IODT refers to the process of verifying that different devices and systems can work together seamlessly, exchanging data and performing functions as intended across varied platforms and vendors.

An IOM is a hardware or software component responsible for handling input and output operations in a computing or control system, facilitating communication between the system and external devices or networks.
Legal rights that protect creations of the mind such as patents, trademarks, and copyrights, granting the creator exclusive rights to use and distribute their intellectual assets.
Fundamental protocol for relaying packets across network boundaries in computer networks, providing addressing and routing functionality for communication over the internet.
Company that provides internet access services to customers
Internet Protocol implementation in the OSI network model layer 3
Routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data using path labels rather than long network addresses
Gateway that enables SMS delivery over IP networks in telecommunications systems
Administration and monitoring of IP address space within a network
Protocol suite for securing Internet Protocol communications through authentication and encryption
a circuit-switched telephone network system that transmits both data and voice over a digital line
IoT refers to the network of interconnected physical devices embedded with sensors, software, and connectivity capabilities that enable them to collect, exchange, and act on data autonomously
The collaborative efforts between two or more organizations aimed at developing new products, services, or processes through shared resources and expertise

A lightweight, text-based data interchange format that is both human-readable and machine-parseable. JSON has become the de facto standard for web APIs and configuration files, using a simple syntax of key-value pairs and arrays to represent complex data structures.

In the context of Transformer-based language models, a KV Cache is an optimization technique used during autoregressive decoding (text generation). It stores the computed key and value vectors from previous attention layers for previously generated tokens, so they don't need to be recomputed for subsequent tokens, speeding up inference.
An AI model trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like language.
A software metric used to measure the size of a computer program by counting the number of lines in the text of the program's source code. Used for estimating programming productivity or effort.

A parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) technique that freezes pre-trained model weights and injects trainable rank decomposition matrices into each layer of the Transformer architecture. This significantly reduces the number of trainable parameters when adapting large models to specific tasks, making fine-tuning more efficient.

A specific path through an MPLS network followed by a packet based on its label. LSPs provide a mechanism for traffic engineering and establishing predetermined paths for data flow, enabling QoS guarantees and efficient routing.

A routing protocol where routers exchange information about their direct network connections to build a complete map of network topology. This enables efficient route calculation and rapid convergence after network changes.
An advanced Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) technology using a large number of antennas (e.g., dozens or hundreds) at the base station to improve spectral efficiency, capacity, and coverage.
a virtual banking system, money transfer, payments and micro-financing service that provides transaction services through a SIM card.

A process where a machine learning model pre-annotates data, and human annotators then review, correct, and validate these annotations. This approach aims to speed up the data labeling process and improve annotation consistency, especially for large datasets. It's a form of human-in-the-loop machine learning.
An open standard that enables AI systems to connect and interact with external tools, data sources, and services through a standardized interface.

moves the computing of traffic and services from a centralized cloud to the edge of the network and closer to the customer. Instead of sending all data to a cloud for processing, the network edge analyses, processes, and stores the data.
A field of artificial intelligence focused on building systems that can learn from and make decisions based on data.

A set of practices that aims to deploy and maintain machine learning models in production reliably and efficiently. It combines ML, DevOps, and Data Engineering to automate and streamline the ML lifecycle, including data gathering, model training, deployment, monitoring, and governance.
A protocol used by IPv6 routers to discover multicast listeners on a directly attached link, part of the ICMPv6 suite.
An extension to the Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) for setting up point-to-multipoint (P2MP) and multipoint-to-multipoint (MP2MP) Label Switched Paths (LSPs) for multicast traffic.
A key control node in the LTE Evolved Packet Core (EPC) responsible for idle mode UE tracking, paging procedures, and bearer activation/deactivation processes.

A machine learning technique, often used in large neural networks, where multiple specialized "expert" sub-models are combined. A gating network determines which expert(s) process a given input, allowing models to scale capacity efficiently without proportionally increasing computational cost for every input.
A service that enables mobile phone users to retain their mobile telephone number when changing from one mobile network carrier to another.
A network sharing configuration where multiple core network operators connect to a shared Radio Access Network (RAN).
A specific instance of a Managed Object Class within a network management model (e.g., in TMN or 3GPP management frameworks), representing a manageable network resource.
A detailed, step-by-step document outlining the actions required to perform a specific network task, change, or maintenance activity safely and correctly.
A network sharing configuration where multiple operators share the same Radio Access Network (RAN) infrastructure.
A routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data using short path labels rather than long network addresses, avoiding complex lookups in a routing table.
A profile of MPLS designed specifically for transport networks, providing carrier-grade OAM (Operations, Administration, and Maintenance) and protection switching capabilities similar to SDH/SONET.
A dedicated cellular network tailored for a specific enterprise or organization, providing enhanced security, control, performance, and coverage for specific business needs.
A lightweight, publish/subscribe network protocol that transports messages between devices. Ideal for constrained devices and low-bandwidth, high-latency networks, commonly used in IoT.
A receiver diversity technique where signals from multiple antennas are weighted and combined to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the resultant signal.
A component in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) architecture that provides media-related functions such as conferencing, transcoding, media announcements, and interactive voice response (IVR).
The server component (control plane) of a Mobile Switching Center (MSC) in GSM/UMTS networks, responsible for call control, mobility management, and supplementary services for circuit-switched calls.
A protocol used between multicast routers, specifically Rendezvous Points (RPs) in different PIM-SM domains, to share information about active multicast sources.
Part of the International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), uniquely identifying a mobile subscription within the home Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN).

definition: Mobile Station International Subscriber Directory Number
description: The globally unique phone number allocated to a mobile subscriber, used for routing calls and messages to the subscriber.
A network element acting as a proxy server that handles multiple services or protocols, often used for mediation or interworking.
Refers to a call, message (e.g., SMS), or data session that originates from the network and terminates at the mobile device (User Equipment).
An application server within the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) architecture that provides supplementary services for multimedia telephony, such as call waiting, call forwarding, and conferencing.
A measure of the predicted elapsed time between inherent failures of a mechanical or electronic system during normal system operation. Represents reliability.
A basic measure of the maintainability of repairable items. It represents the average time required to repair a failed component or device.
Allows a base station (e.g., Wi-Fi AP or cellular base station) to communicate with multiple user devices simultaneously using the same time and frequency resources through spatial multiplexing.

definition: Mandatory Use-case requirements for SDN for Transport
description: An IETF draft defining mandatory functional requirements for applying Software-Defined Networking (SDN) principles to transport networks.
The self-service mobile application provided by Vodacom for its customers to manage their accounts, services, and usage.
Value-Added Services delivered over mobile networks, beyond standard voice calls and SMS, such as ringback tones, mobile money, location-based services, etc.
A version of a new product which allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort.
Electromagnetic waves in the frequency range of 300 MHz to 300 GHz, commonly used for point-to-point communication links in telecommunications backhaul and fixed wireless access.
Activities related to keeping network equipment, software, and services operational, including troubleshooting, repairs, updates, and technical assistance.
A concept referring to seamless user experiences and service continuity across multiple devices (e.g., phone, tablet, PC) and potentially multiple user identities or profiles.
an interface that allows the component to communicate with a higher-level component, using the latter component's southbound interface. The languages or protocols commonly used include SNMP and TL1.

A subtask of information extraction that seeks to locate and classify named entities in unstructured text into pre-defined categories such as person names, organizations, locations, medical codes, time expressions, quantities, monetary values, percentages, etc. NER systems are crucial for many NLP applications like question answering, machine translation, and information retrieval.
A subfield of NLP focused on producing natural language text from structured data or computational representations.

A branch of artificial intelligence focused on enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language in useful ways. NLP combines computational linguistics, machine learning, and deep learning to process and analyze large amounts of natural language data.
A subfield of NLP focused on machine reading comprehension and understanding the meaning of text.

definition: Network Service Platform – Transport Slicing Controller

description: A business and technology model where network capabilities (e.g., bandwidth on demand, location services, security functions) are exposed as programmable services via APIs for internal or external developers.

definition: Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards

description: a small operating system, pre-installed as firmware on bare metal network switches, that provides an environment for automated operating system provisioning
equipment that use optical fibers to transmit data signals. They are used in a variety of applications, including long-distance transmission, metropolitan area networks (MANs), and access networks.

A dense decoder-only Transformer model developed by Google, trained on the Pathways system. It is known for its large scale (e.g., 540 billion parameters) and strong performance on a wide range of language tasks, including reasoning and code generation.
Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol
A networking technology that translates multiple local ports to a single public IP address

a device that computes paths on behalf of the nodes in the network. It can be a router, a COTS server, part of the OSS, or a virtualized entity running in a cloud. When a network node needs a path for an LSP, it makes a request to the PCE using the PCE protocol (PCEP). The PCE has access to topology information for the entire network and uses this in path computations.
a special set of rules that allows a Path Computation Client (PCC) to request path computations from Path Computation Elements (PCEs)
Information that is delivered as a unit between peer entities of a network

A set of techniques used to adapt large pre-trained models (like LLMs) to new tasks by fine-tuning only a small subset of their parameters, or by adding a small number of new parameters. This reduces computational and storage costs compared to full fine-tuning. Examples include LoRA, prompt tuning, and adapter layers.
A family of multicast routing protocols for IP networks that provide one-to-many and many-to-many distribution

The smallest unit of radio resources that can be allocated to a user in LTE and 5G NR systems. A PRB consists of 12 consecutive subcarriers in the frequency domain and a slot in the time domain. PRBs are fundamental to resource scheduling and determining system capacity in cellular networks.

PTP, standardized as IEEE 1588, is crucial for achieving sub-microsecond synchronization across networked systems. Recent studies highlight its vulnerabilities to internal attacks, prompting the development of security enhancements like Trusted Supervisor Nodes (TSNs) to bolster its resilience.

Modern PTT services have evolved beyond traditional walkie-talkie functionality, integrating with LTE and VoIP technologies to provide robust communication solutions in various scenarios, including emergency response and disaster relief.
PWAs combine the flexibility of the web with the experience of a native application, allowing users to install web apps to their home screen, receive push notifications, and work offline
A cloud computing model where a third-party provider delivers hardware and software tools for application development
Highest level on aggregation network hierarchy, connects to the core network.
Intermediate aggregation level between POC1 and POC3, sometimes aggregates Cell Sites directly. Normally connected to POC1 in ring architectures or slightly meshed, always with optical fibre.
First aggregation point in the hierarchy after last mile/access
A demonstration of a solution's business value and ROI, typically following a PoC
The practice of designing and refining input prompts to guide generative AI models towards desired outputs.

A high-level, interpreted programming language emphasizing code readability and simplicity. Python's extensive standard library and rich ecosystem of third-party packages make it popular for web development, scientific computing, data analysis, artificial intelligence, and automation tasks.

In the context of machine translation, QE refers to the automatic prediction of translation quality without reference translations. Recent approaches employ multi-task learning and pre-trained language models to enhance the accuracy of QE systems.

definition: Quad Small Form-factor Pluggable Dual Density

description: The QnQ model integrates both the quality and quantity of user contributions to assess trustworthiness in participatory sensing applications. This dual-faceted approach aims to mitigate the impact of malicious or low-quality data submissions.

QoE encompasses the overall user satisfaction with a service, influenced by factors like network performance and content delivery. Advanced models now utilize machine learning to predict QoE, enabling proactive optimization of user experiences.

An efficient fine-tuning technique for large language models that combines LoRA with quantization. QLoRA reduces memory usage significantly by quantizing the pre-trained model to 4-bit precision and then fine-tuning a small number of adapter parameters (LoRA) on top of the quantized model. This allows fine-tuning very large models on limited hardware.
An AI technique that combines a retrieval system (to find relevant information) with a generative model (to create an answer).
a fixed radio transceiver that provides wireless communication coverage to a specific geographic area

part of the digital microwave transmission system. It supports a point-to-point digital fixed radio service and long-haul wireless transmission system. The RFU works together with the Indoor Unit (IDU) to provide multiple types of service interfaces.

An AI model, particularly in the context of language processing, that is designed or fine-tuned to excel at retrieving relevant information from a large corpus of documents or a knowledge base in response to a query. These models are often a core component of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.

A machine learning technique that combines reinforcement learning with human feedback to align AI models, particularly large language models, with human preferences and desired behaviors. Human evaluators rank or rate model outputs, and this feedback is used to train a reward model, which then guides the fine-tuning of the LLM.
A type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties.
Traffic Engineering

SD-WAN applies SDN principles to WAN connections, allowing for intelligent routing, improved performance, and centralized management across multiple network paths, enhancing connectivity for distributed enterprises.

SDC, particularly in medical device networks, leverages IEEE 11073 standards and Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) to enable semantic interoperability and real-time communication, facilitating automatic configuration and ensuring safety-critical operations.

SDDC abstracts and virtualizes all data center resources, including compute, storage, and networking, allowing for centralized management and automation, thus enhancing scalability and operational efficiency.
A set of 17 global goals established by the United Nations in 2015, aimed at addressing global challenges such as poverty, inequality, climate change, and environmental degradation by 2030.

SDH is a standardized protocol for transmitting large volumes of data over optical fiber networks, offering high-speed, synchronized data transfer and facilitating efficient multiplexing of digital signals.

An SDK is a collection of software tools and libraries that developers use to create applications for specific platforms, providing APIs, documentation, and debugging tools to streamline development processes.
SDL enhances mobile network capacity by utilizing unpaired spectrum for downlink transmission, improving data throughput and user experience, especially in data-intensive applications.

SDN decouples the control plane from the data plane in networking equipment, enabling centralized control, programmability, and dynamic management of network resources, thus fostering innovation and flexibility.

A process of adapting a pre-trained model (often a large language model) to a specific downstream task by further training it on a labeled dataset relevant to that task. SFT uses input-output pairs (e.g., prompt-response) to teach the model the desired behavior or knowledge for the target application. It is a common step in preparing LLMs for specialized use cases.
An iterative optimization algorithm used to minimize a function by updating parameters in the opposite direction of the gradient of the function with respect to the parameters.

definition: Security and Privacy by Design Assurance

description: SR simplifies network operations by encoding paths as sequences of segments, enabling scalable and flexible traffic engineering. Recent studies focus on SR's integration with MPLS and IPv6, highlighting its benefits in reducing protocol overhead and enhancing network programmability.

SR technology has advanced with deep learning models, enabling more accurate and robust transcription of spoken language. Research emphasizes the use of large-scale datasets and neural networks to improve recognition in diverse and noisy environments.

SR OS is a network operating system designed for high-performance IP routing. It supports advanced features like segment routing and integrates with various network management protocols to enhance scalability and reliability.

Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) allows multiple virtual machines to share a single physical network interface card, improving I/O efficiency and reducing latency. Research explores its applications in cloud computing and data center environments.

SR-TE combines segment routing with traffic engineering principles to optimize network resource utilization. Research highlights its ability to provide efficient path computation and fast reroute capabilities.

Sounding Reference Signals (SRS) are used in wireless communication systems to estimate uplink channel conditions. Studies focus on optimizing SRS allocation to enhance channel state information accuracy, crucial for technologies like massive MIMO.
SRVCC enables seamless handover of voice calls from LTE to legacy networks. Research discusses its implementation challenges and solutions to maintain call quality during transitions.

SS7 is a set of protocols used for exchanging information in public switched telephone networks. Recent studies address its security vulnerabilities and propose measures to protect against potential threats.
SSBs are used in 5G networks for cell search and initial access procedures. Research focuses on their design and role in beamforming to improve coverage and capacity in high-frequency bands.

definition: Signalling Connection Control Part User Adaptation Layer

description: A supervised machine learning algorithm used for classification and regression tasks by finding the optimal hyperplane that separates data into classes.
SeGW provides secure communication in mobile networks by handling authentication, encryption, and authorization processes, ensuring data integrity and protecting against unauthorized access.
connection-oriented transport protocol used over IP to ensure reliable transmission of packets

Interface traffic is carried through the radio frequency in the air. Data is compressed for efficient transmission of data. Original data of 64 KBPS on interface side is compressed to 13 KBPS on the air. The compression is done by TCSM.

definition: Topology and Orchestration Specification for Cloud Applications

description: A structured document used to deliver detailed technical findings, methodologies, or analyses from engineering or scientific research, often preceding formal publication [[BytePlus]](https://www.byteplus.com/en/technical-report-meaning-types-structure).

A plan detailing procedures for the restoration of critical IT systems, applications, and data following a disruption, ensuring minimal downtime and service continuity [[TechTarget]](https://www.techtarget.com/searchdisasterrecovery/Definition/business-continuity-and-disaster-recovery-BCDR).

A formalized set of documented requirements that define the system's functionality, performance, and interface constraints, serving as a baseline for development and validation [[ScienceDirect]](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S240593262030077X).

A full-duplex communication module capable of both transmitting and receiving signals within wireless systems, commonly implemented in radio transceivers and mobile network devices [[IEEE Xplore]](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6823165).
A strategy-level document that defines the tasks and duties required of a project contractor, and highlights project background and objectives at high level.

A prompting framework that generalizes Chain of Thought (CoT) by enabling language models to explore multiple reasoning paths for problem-solving. It allows the model to generate diverse intermediate thoughts (a 'tree' of thoughts), evaluate their viability, and use search algorithms (like breadth-first or depth-first search) to navigate these paths and find more robust solutions.
A deep learning model architecture introduced in 'Attention Is All You Need', heavily used in NLP and other sequence tasks.
A system that combines and analyzes customer data from multiple sources to provide comprehensive customer insights
A centralized system for managing digital certificates and PKI infrastructure across an organization

definition: User Data Interworking, Coexistence and Migration

description: A platform for managing and coordinating event-driven communications across distributed systems
A security approach that enables organizations to manage and secure all endpoints (mobile, desktop, IoT) from a single platform
A storage system that provides a unified view of multiple file systems and storage resources
IPv6 address type intended for local communications within a site or organization
Technology enabling seamless roaming between cellular and Wi-Fi networks
System for analyzing user behavior patterns and profile data to derive actionable insights
Centralized storage and management system for security and access control policies
Comprehensive security approach combining multiple security technologies and protocols
A type of generative model that learns a probabilistic mapping from input data to a latent space.

An AI model that can process and understand information from both visual (images, videos) and textual modalities. VLMs are capable of tasks such as image captioning, visual question answering (VQA), and generating text based on visual input. They integrate computer vision and natural language processing techniques.

Enables broadband connectivity in remote areas, supporting IoT deployments and critical operations in sectors like energy and maritime. Recent studies highlight its role in bridging the digital divide and facilitating real-time data transmission where terrestrial infrastructure is lacking.

Consolidates multiple physical switches into a single logical entity, enhancing network redundancy and simplifying management. Research emphasizes its benefits in reducing downtime and improving network resilience.
Establishes a unified framework for technology deployment across Vodafone's global operations, streamlining processes and accelerating the adoption of emerging technologies like 5G and IoT.
A regulatory approach that allows alternative operators to access incumbent networks at a virtual level, facilitating competition in broadband services and promoting market entry and innovation.
A telecommunications network that extends over a large geographical area for primary purpose of computer networking
A third-generation (3G) mobile telecommunications technology that supports high-speed data transmission
A wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network within a limited area
A security protocol developed for wireless networks to address vulnerabilities found in earlier protocols
A network of distributed autonomous devices that use sensors to monitor physical or environmental conditions
The ability of a model to perform a task it hasn't been explicitly trained on, often by understanding instructions in the prompt.

An approach to security management that leverages automation, AI, and ML techniques to enable fully automated end-to-end network and service security management without human intervention. It aims to detect, analyze, and mitigate security threats in real-time across multiple technological domains while maintaining service continuity and performance.
Refers to the spectrum band between 30 GHz and 300 GHz. Used in 5G NR for providing high data rates and capacity, typically over shorter distances due to higher propagation loss.

An enhancement of the traditional Spanning Tree Protocol, allowing for per-VLAN spanning tree instances. Studies demonstrate its effectiveness in optimizing network performance by preventing loops and improving convergence times in complex VLAN environments.

A network architecture that enables the creation of multiple virtual networks on top of a shared physical infrastructure. Each network slice is an isolated end-to-end network tailored to fulfill specific requirements requested by a particular application or service. Network slicing is a key capability of 5G and beyond networks, allowing operators to provide customized connectivity with specific performance characteristics (bandwidth, latency, reliability) for different use cases simultaneously.

An ETSI-defined framework for the management and orchestration of virtualized network functions in NFV environments. MANO consists of three main components: the NFV Orchestrator (NFVO) for resource/service orchestration, the VNF Manager (VNFM) for lifecycle management of VNF instances, and the Virtualized Infrastructure Manager (VIM) for controlling and managing NFV infrastructure resources. MANO enables automated deployment, configuration, and coordination of virtualized network services.

The comprehensive process of managing the entire lifecycle of a network service, function, or slice from instantiation through operation to termination. In virtualized and cloud-native environments, LCM includes automated processes for onboarding, instantiation, scaling, healing, updating, and decommissioning of network functions and services. Modern LCM approaches emphasize closed-loop automation and policy-driven management to reduce operational complexity and enable dynamic resource optimization.

A term referring to the evolution and enhancement of 5G technologies and the transition toward 6G. Beyond 5G encompasses advanced technologies and concepts that extend current 5G capabilities, including terahertz communications, integrated sensing and communication, AI-native networks, holographic communications, and quantum networking. It aims to address limitations of 5G while laying the groundwork for future 6G systems, with research focusing on extreme performance, sustainability, and novel applications.

The sixth generation of wireless technology expected to succeed 5G in the 2030s. 6G aims to provide significantly enhanced capabilities including terabit-per-second data rates, microsecond latency, extremely high reliability, and support for advanced applications like holographic communications, extended reality, and digital twins. Key enabling technologies include terahertz communications, intelligent surfaces, AI-native networking, quantum communications, and integrated sensing and communication. 6G research emphasizes sustainability, trustworthiness, and human-centric design.
